bibl.title: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, December 10, 1901

div1.p: Howard thanks Reed for the copies of two papers on yellow fever. He then corrects Reed on the proper way to spell out fasciata Stegomyia. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from L. O. Howard to Walter Reed, December 10, 1901
div1.p:
Thank you greatly for the copies of the two extreme-
ly important papers, “The Prevention of Yellow Fever” and “The
Propagation of Yellow Fever.” I am very glad to get these papers at
this time, since, especially in the former, there are many notes on
the yellow fever mosquito which I wish to incorporate in the revised
edition of the Mosquito book, which I hope will be published in the
spring. Will you allow me to call your attention to the fact that
the specific name fasciata should always begin with a small letter,
unless occurring at the beginning of a sentence, and the generic
name, Stegomyia, always with a capital. See legends to all figures
and the print of the scientific name in the text. Under all figures
the “f” of fasciata is wrongly capitalized, and in all text references
to the scientific name the “S” of Stegomyia is erroneously placed in
lower case. The figures are very pretty. The paper as a whole
is of the most intense interest.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, L. O. Howard Dr. Walter Reed,
U. A. Army Medical Museum,
City.
